Article Title: When Melania Trump’s cryptocurrency token wiped $5 billion from Donald Trump’s memecoin
Article Text: Donald Trump's cryptocurrency token dropped 38% in value on Friday after his wife Melania Trump launched her own competing digital coin, erasing $5 billion from the token's market capitalization just days before his presidential inauguration.The TRUMP token's price fell from $74.60 to $45.90 within 40 minutes of Melania Trump announcing her own MELANIA token, according to CoinMarketCap data. Meanwhile, the First Lady-elect's new cryptocurrency skyrocketed to a $6.14 billion market value within two hours of launch."It's time to celebrate everything we stand for: WINNING! Join my very special Trump Community," Donald Trump posted on social media on January 17, promoting his token. The marketing featured Trump with a raised fist alongside "FIGHT FIGHT FIGHT," referencing his response to an assassination attempt during a July political rally.Over 45,000 digital wallets have purchased the MELANIA token since its launch Thursday evening, though blockchain analytics platform Bubblemaps reported that nearly 90% of the token supply is held in a single wallet, contradicting the project's claimed distribution structure.Critics warn these politically-linked tokens could enable undue influence from special interests and foreign entities. "If people want to gamble, I don't really care," said Lee Reiners, a former Federal Reserve economist now at Duke University. "What I care about is when this crypto bubble bursts -- and it will burst -- it will end up impacting people across the economy even if they don't have direct investment in crypto."Supporters view the Trump memecoin as symbolic of the incoming president's pro-cryptocurrency stance, which contrasts with the perceived hostility of the outgoing Biden administration. Trump has pledged to implement crypto-friendly regulations and has appointed industry advocates to key government positions.The TRUMP token initially sold for $10 before surging to $70 by Sunday morning. The token's website claims 35% was distributed to the team, with other allocations for treasury, community, public sale and liquidity.
Article Summary: Donald Trump's Trump token fell from $74.60 to $45.90 within 40 minutes of his wife's launch. The MELANIA token skyrocketed to a $6.14 billion market value within two hours of launch. Critics warn these politically-linked tokens could enable undue influence.

Article Title: Niti Aayog, Nasscom foundation partner to digitally empower 1 lakh people
Article Text:
Training under the programme

Nasscom Foundation , in partnership with NITI Aayog , is digitally empowering one lakh lives in India’s Aspirational Blocks , it has announced. The initial phase of the initiative – aligned with the Pradhan Mantri Digital Saksharta Abhiyan – focuses on bridging the digital divide by providing digital literacy training and access to essential e-governance services across 60 Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups (PVTG) blocks.The program will expand to include all other aspirational blocks. By promoting digital inclusion, this initiative supports the government’s vision of Viksit Bharat, fostering inclusive growth and ensuring that no one is left behind in India’s digital transformation journey.It said that the programme is built on the success of Nasscom Foundation’s Aspirational Districts Programme launched in 2022 and focuses on bridging the digital divide across 55 aspirational districts across 23 states through Digital Resource Centres.According to the Tribal Development Report 2022, the literacy rate among PVTGs is just 47.7%, far below the national average of 77.3% which makes the scenario of digital growth extremely vital in these communities.To address this disparity, nasscom foundation has extended the initiative from aspirational districts to blocks by focusing on communities including women and youth between the ages of 12 and 60, equipping them with essential digital skills and resources to foster holistic growth and inclusion.The training encompasses foundational computer skills, cybersecurity, and effective internet usage, enabling participants to navigate the digital world. Community outreach campaigns are also a part of the initiative, raising awareness about the benefits of digital literacy and e-governance services while encouraging the adoption of digital tools.The programme enlists local community champions as master trainers and digital ambassadors to lead these efforts.
Article Summary: Nasscom Foundation, in partnership with NITI Aayog, is digitally empowering one lakh lives in India’s Aspirational Blocks. The initial phase of the initiative – aligned with the Pradhan Mantri Digital Saksharta Abhiyan – focuses on bridging the digital divide.

Article Title: YouTube, Facebook and X agrees to Europe’s new tech rules: Here’s what is next
Article Text:
Representative Image

What is the new code of conduct and what EU said about it



"In Europe there is no place for illegal hate, either offline or online. I welcome the stakeholders' commitment to a strengthened Code of conduct under the

Digital Services Act

(DSA).”

Major tech companies including Meta 's Facebook , Elon Musk's X (earlier Twitter), Google's YouTube and others have agreed to strengthen their efforts against online hate speech under an updated code of conduct that will be incorporated into the European Union’s (EU) tech rules. According to a report by the news agency Reuters, the European Commission has announced that these companies, along with other signatories to the voluntary code established in May 2016, have committed to taking further action to combat the spread of hate speech. Several other tech companies have also signed the voluntary code of conduct to combat online hate speech, including Dailymotion, Instagram, Jeuxvideo.com, LinkedIn, Microsoft-hosted consumer services, Snapchat, Rakuten Viber, TikTok and Twitch.Under the updated code, companies have committed to allowing not-for-profit or public organisations with expertise in illegal hate speech to oversee their handling of hate speech notices. They also agreed to review at least two-thirds of such notices within 24 hours.Additionally, the companies will implement measures, including the use of automated detection tools, to minimise hate speech on their platforms. These companies will also provide transparency on the role of recommendation systems and the organic and algorithmic reach of illegal content before its removal.The companies will also offer country-specific data, categorised by internal classifications of hate speech, such as race, ethnicity, religion, gender identity, or sexual orientation.In a statement to Reuters, EU tech commissioner Henna Virkkunen said:The DSA mandates that tech companies take stronger action against illegal and harmful content on their platforms. According to EU officials, adhering to the updated code could influence how regulators enforce the Act.
Article Summary: Major tech companies have agreed to strengthen their efforts against online hate speech under an updated code of conduct. The updated code will be incorporated into the European Union’s (EU) tech rules. Under the updated code, companies will allow not-for-profit or public organisations with expertise in illegal hate speech to oversee their handling of hate speech notices.

Article Title: Microsoft search market share doubles, as Google's share falls just below 90% for the first time
Article Text:
How Google's search market share dropped

Google's dominance in the global search engine market has dipped below 90% for the first time in almost a decade. According to Statcounter, in the last three months of 2024, Google's market share fell to 89.34% in October, 89.99% in November, and 89.74% in December. This marks a significant shift in the search landscape, as Google has consistently held over 90% of the market share for almost a decade. The last time Google's share was below 90% was in early 2015.However, this decline has helped Microsoft 's Bing search engine to experience a major growth in usage during the latter half of 2024, with its market share almost doubling to reach around 4%. This suggests that Bing is slowly gaining popularity, although it still lags significantly behind Google.As per Statcounter data, Google seems to be gradually losing its search market share. The company’s search market share has remained relatively stable in most regions except Asia, which appears to be a significant factor behind the overall decline, the report suggests.In the US, Google’s search market share peaked at 90.37% in November 2024 but dropped to 87.39% by December. For the rest of 2024, the share fluctuated between 86-88%, showing a slight but noticeable decline.Despite dominating the search market for nearly a decade with a consistent 90-92+% share, Google has faced criticism over the growing unhelpfulness of its search results.This, along with allegations of maintaining an illegal monopoly, has placed the company under scrutiny for almost two years.While Google's search market share decline might suggest users are turning to AI-powered search engines like ChatGPT Search and Perplexity, Statcounter's data doesn't specifically mention that. The report primarily tracks traditional search engines like Bing, Yandex, and Yahoo , with a minor "other" category that includes DuckDuckGo and Ecosia.Microsoft's Bing, the second most popular search engine, saw a slight increase in market share, hovering around 4% in the latter half of 2024.It's worth noting that a similar dip in Google's market share in April 2024 turned out to be a data error. However, the consistent decline in the last three months of 2024 suggests a real shift in user behaviour, even if the specific reasons remain unclear.
Article Summary: Google's market share fell to 89.34% in October, 89.99% in November, and 89.74% in December. This marks a significant shift in the search landscape, as Google has consistently held over 90% of the market share for almost a decade. Microsoft's Bing saw a slight increase in market share, hovering around 4% in the latter half of 2024.

You know, it’s appropriate. We have to look at it carefully. It’s a very big situation,” Trump added.“If I decide to do that, I'll probably announce it on Monday,” Trump noted.The bipartisan law passed last year explicitly permits a 90-day extension under specific conditions. However, even if an extension is granted on Monday, it may not prevent the app from going dark for at least a day, as the current compliance deadline is Sunday.The Chinese-owned app stated last week that it will go dark in the US on Sunday unless President Joe Biden's administration provides assurances to companies like Apple and Google that they will not face enforcement actions when the ban takes effect.The White House, however, dismissed TikTok's Friday comment as a stunt, reiterating that it was up to the incoming Trump administration to take action, increasing the likelihood of a shutdown on Sunday.“We see no reason for TikTok or other companies to take actions in the next few days before the Trump administration takes office on Monday,” press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said in a statement.Meanwhile, the Chinese embassy in Washington accused the US of using unfair state power to suppress TikTok.“China will take all necessary measures to resolutely safeguard its legitimate rights and interests,” a spokesperson said.The US Supreme Court justices upheld the ban in a unanimous decision.
Article Summary: TikTok faces a shutdown in the US on Sunday if it doesn't comply with a ban. President-elect Donald Trump has said he will grant a 90-day reprieve from the ban. Article Title: China 'wakes up' to 'Made-in-India' iPhones with 'restrictions' on manufacturing partners
Article Text:
China denies restrictions

Trump factor behind the 'wake-up' call

China seems to be finally taking note of Apple and other technology and auto companies moving manufacturing/assembly to India and other parts of the world. According to a report in Bloomberg, China is making it harder for employees and specialised equipment needed for high-tech manufacturing in India and Southeast Asia to leave its borders. The report that quotes people familiar with the matter added that this is possibly an attempt to prevent companies from shifting production in anticipation of higher tariffs under US President-elect Donald Trump Sources familiar with the matter indicate that Beijing has informally advised regulatory agencies and local governments to limit technology transfers and equipment exports to these regions. The goal is to bolster domestic production, mitigate potential job losses, and discourage foreign investors from leaving China if the US imposes new trade barriers.For example, Apple's primary assembly partner, Foxconn, has reportedly faced difficulties in deploying Chinese staff to its Indian factory and in receiving specialized machinery from China. While these issues haven't yet impacted production, they highlight the potential implications of these restrictions. Sources reportedly indicate that Apple's China-based equipment partners have faced increased scrutiny from Chinese government officials regarding shipments of equipment to India. Recent reports also claimed that Apple and Foxconn sought help from the Indian government regarding the same. Apple and Foxconn are said to have sought urgent help from the Indian government for assistance as specialized manufacturing equipment faces significant delays at Chinese ports, threatening to impact India's electronics manufacturing expansion plans.China's foreign ministry has stated that it treats all countries equally and welcomes enterprises from everywhere, denying any actions that harm other nations. However, reports suggest that Beijing is particularly concerned about Foxconn further diversifying its production away from China, given the company's significant workforce and its importance to local supply chains and employment.This trend of companies shifting production away from China, which began during Trump's first term, is expected to accelerate and potentially include more technology companies. The restrictions on tech equipment are also reportedly affecting the manufacturing of electric vehicles (EVs) and solar panels in India, impacting companies like BYD and Waaree Energies. Previous reports indicated that Beijing aimed to limit the transfer of advanced EV manufacturing technology and had advised automakers against investing in India.
Article Summary: Beijing is making it harder for employees and specialised equipment needed for high-tech manufacturing in India and Southeast Asia to leave its borders. This is possibly an attempt to prevent companies from shifting production in anticipation of higher tariffs under US President-elect Donald Trump. The goal is to bolster domestic production, mitigate potential job losses, and discourage foreign investors from leaving China.

Article Title: Apple removes TikTok and other ByteDance apps from US App Store: Check the list here
Article Text: In a rare move, Apple has published a statement and a support document listing all the apps removed from its US. App Store alongside TikTok due to a federal ban. The ban, enforced under the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, requires ByteDance to either sell TikTok or face a nationwide ban due to national security concerns.The list of removed apps includes several ByteDance-owned applications such as CapCut , Lemon8 , TikTok Studio, TikTok Shop Seller Center, Hypic, Lark – Team Collaboration, Lark – Rooms Display, Lark Rooms Controller, Gauth: AI Study Companion, and MARVEL SNAP. Apple emphasised that it is obligated to follow the laws in the jurisdictions where it operates and that these apps will no longer be available for download or updates in the United States starting January 19, 2025.“TikTok and ByteDance Ltd. apps are no longer available in the United States, and visitors to the United States might have limited access to features. Apple is obligated to follow the laws in the jurisdictions where it operates. Pursuant to the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, apps developed by ByteDance Ltd. and its subsidiaries — including TikTok, CapCut, Lemon8, and others — will no longer be available for download or updates on the App Store for users in the United States starting January 19, 2025,” said Apple in a statement.Visitors to the US with the App Store set to a non-U.S. region will not be able to update the apps or purchase in-app items. Apple also noted that users who already have these apps installed on their devices will not be able to redownload them if deleted or switch to a new device.Apple's decision to publish the list of removed apps is a departure from its usual practice of not disclosing information when it blocks apps. The company has assured users that it is working to restore services in the US and will keep them updated on any developments.
Article Summary: The ban, enforced under the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, requires ByteDance to either sell TikTok or face a nationwide ban. Apple emphasised that it is obligated to follow the laws in the jurisdictions where it operates and that these apps will no longer be available for download or updates in the United States.

Article Title: TikTok stops working in US; app now reads this ban message
Article Text:
Why US banned TikTok

What’s next for TikTok

TikTok has stopped working in the US, reports Reuters. This means people in the US can no longer use the popular short-video platform. After months of legal battles, the US Supreme Court on Friday, January 17 approved a law to ban TikTok, citing national security concerns . TikTok users in the US now see this message when they open the app:“A law banning TikTok has been enacted in the U.S.Unfortunately, that means you can't use TikTok for now. We are fortunate that President Trump has indicated that he will work with us on a solution to reinstate TikTok once he takes office. Please stay tuned”.US officials have raised concerns about TikTok, claiming it poses a national security risk. They believe the Chinese government could use the app to spy on Americans or secretly influence public opinion by controlling what content is shown or hidden.The worry stems from Chinese national security laws that require companies to assist with intelligence activities. FBI Director Christopher Wray told Congress last year that the Chinese government could potentially access and compromise Americans’ devices through TikTok’s software.These concerns led the US Congress to pass a law banning TikTok unless its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, sold it to a buyer approved by the U.S. government. President Joe Biden signed the law in April 2024, giving ByteDance until January 19 to sell TikTok. However, ByteDance's attempt to challenge the law in court failed. On December 6, a panel of three federal judges unanimously ruled against TikTok, rejecting its argument that the law violated free speech rights under the First Amendment.The Supreme Court unanimously rejected TikTok’s appeal on January 17, resulting in the ban coming into effect on January 19.The future of TikTok in the U.S. remains uncertain. Over time, the app is expected to stop functioning properly, as updates and support from app stores like Apple and Google would be blocked under the new law. Eventually, TikTok could become completely unusable in the country.All eyes are now on President-elect Donald Trump, who is set to take office on January 20. In a statement to NBC recently, Trump referred to the TikTok situation as a "very big situation" and said he is planning to push back a potential TikTok ban for 90 days.Until then, TikTok users and businesses that relied on the app for growth face an uncertain future, as the app has already stopped working in the US.
Article Summary: US officials have raised concerns about TikTok, claiming it poses a national security risk. They believe the Chinese government could use the app to spy on Americans or secretly influence public opinion by controlling what content is shown or hidden. The future of TikTok in the U.S. remains uncertain.
